content:
John Baez said:

I explained it here:

  • John Baez, Spans versus bimodules, August 4, 2008.

I don't know if that counts as an explanation. It is a super interesting topic. You posed a puzzle, a bunch of smart people gave answers, but I don't really see any explanations there :thinking:
John Baez said:

When you understand this you'll be happy. I tried to explain it here on Zulip a while back, but you probably weren't desperate enough back then.

For sure I will be happy :blush: I'll try to find your explanation again :pray:

The answers to the puzzles are the explanation. The answer to this puzzle:

Puzzle 3: What’s a bimodule of a pair of monoid objects in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm op}Setop?

is a span of sets!

The bimodules you like to think about are bimodules in (Vect,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes)(Vect,⊗). But those are just a special case of a more general concept, and you need to go up a notch in generality to see that spans are also bimodules. It goes like this, briefly:

A set is a monoid object in the monoidal category (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}, +)(Setop,+).

We can define bimodules for monoid objects in any monoidal category.

A span of sets is a bimodule in (Setop,+)(\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}},+)(Setop,+).
I don't expect this to be extremely easy to understand, but it's also not extremely hard.
Thank you. I will try to understand this and come back when I get stuck :pray:
Good luck! You have to do the puzzles in order, because each one depends on understanding the previous ones.

Puzzle 1: What’s a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

The "object" is a set XXX, but for this to be a monoid object, we need a multiplication

μ:X×X→X.\mu: X\times X\to X.μ:X×X→X.

and a unit

η:∗→X\eta: *\to Xη:∗→X

satisfying the conditions. I don't think the answer is complete without specifying those :thinking:

Attempt #1: Before looking at Puzzle #2

I think a multiplication X×X→XX\times X\to XX×X→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→X×XX\to X\times XX→X×X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and the only function that would make sense to me is
{}
x↦(x,x)∈X×X.x\mapsto (x,x)\in X\times X.x↦(x,x)∈X×X.
{}
A unit ∗→X*\to X∗→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→∗X\to *X→∗ in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and that is unique since ∗*∗ is terminal.

A quick doodle confirms these satisfy associativity and unit laws.

Attempt #2: After looking at Puzzle #2, but before looking at Puzzle #3

I now see that I really wanted my monoid object to be a set of functions [X,X][X,X][X,X] (or End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)).

Then multiplication [X,X]×[X,X]→[X,X][X,X]\times [X,X]\to [X,X][X,X]×[X,X]→[X,X] is just composition of functions
{}
f×g↦f∘g\sout{f\times g \mapsto f\circ g}f×g↦f∘g​
{}
and the unit ∗→[X,X]*\to [X,X]∗→[X,X] is the identity function
{}
∙↦1X.\sout{\bullet\mapsto 1_X.}∙↦1X​.​
{}
I don't actually see anything wrong with Attempt #1 though, so I think both might be correct. In that case, it means composition of endofunctions in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is the opposite of the diagonal map of endofunctions in Set.\mathsf{Set}.Set.

Attempt #3: After looking at Puzzle #3

After attempting Puzzle #3, I think I need to come back here again.

There are actually two types of monoid objects in Setop.\mathsf{Set^{op}}.Setop. The first is the one in Attempt #2 above, i.e. the set of functions [X,X][X,X][X,X] (or End(X)\mathsf{End}(X)End(X)).

The second type of monoid object, maybe denote it [X,X]op[X,X]^\mathsf{op}[X,X]op (or Endop(X)\mathsf{End^{op}}(X)Endop(X)). This monoid object is the same set of functions, but multiplication / composition
{}
[X,X]op×[X,X]op→[X,X]op\sout{[X,X]^\mathsf{op}\times[X,X]^\mathsf{op}\to[X,X]^\mathsf{op}}[X,X]op×[X,X]op→[X,X]op​
{}
is reversed, i.e.
{}
f×g↦g∘f.\sout{f\times g\mapsto g\circ f.}f×g↦g∘f.​

Note: I split the stream into one stream for each Puzzle

  1. Puzzle 1 (here)
  2. Puzzle 2
  3. Puzzle 3

so I am quoting John's reply for Puzzle 1 here.

John Baez said:

Eric Forgy said:

Puzzle 1: What’s a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop?

The "object" is a set XXX, but for this to be a monoid object, we need a multiplication

μ:X×X→X.\mu: X\times X\to X.μ:X×X→X.

and a unit

η:∗→X\eta: *\to Xη:∗→X

satisfying the conditions. I don't think the answer is complete without specifying those :thinking:

Attempt #1: Before looking at Puzzle #2

I think a multiplication X×X→XX\times X\to XX×X→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→X×XX\to X\times XX→X×X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and the only function that would make sense to me is
{}
x↦(x,x)∈X×X.x\mapsto (x,x)\in X\times X.x↦(x,x)∈X×X.
{}
A unit ∗→X*\to X∗→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop is a function X→∗X\to *X→∗ in Set\mathsf{Set}Set and that is unique since ∗*∗ is terminal.

A quick doodle confirms these satisfy associativity and unit laws.

Right! And the really cool part is that this is the only possible choice of maps μ:X→X×X\mu: X \to X \times Xμ:X→X×X and η:X→1\eta: X \to 1η:X→1 obeying (co)associativity and the (co)unit laws. (We usually put the word "co" in here since the maps are going backwards.) So while in Set\mathsf{Set}Set you need to specify μ\muμ and η\etaη to say how we are treating our set XXX as a monoid, in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathrm{op}}Setop you don't: there's only one choice!

I've been trying to show that the choices for multiplication μ\muμ and unit η\etaη on a monoid object in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop are forced. We are working in the monoidal category Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop where objects are sets, a morphism f:A→Bf:A \to Bf:A→B is a function from BBB to AAA, the monoidal product ⊗\otimes⊗ is the Cartesian product of sets ×\times×, and the unit object the singleton set {∗}\{*\}{∗}.

A monoid object in this category is a set MMM together with a morphism μ:M×M→M\mu: M \times M \to Mμ:M×M→M and a morphism η:{∗}→M\eta: \{*\} \to Mη:{∗}→M, satisfying associativity and unit laws. Let μop:M→M×M\mu^{op}: M \to M \times Mμop:M→M×M be the function corresponding to μ\muμ, and let ηop:M→{∗}\eta^{op}: M \to \{*\}ηop:M→{∗} be the function corresponding to η\etaη. Notice that ηop\eta^{op}ηop is forced to be the unique function sending every element of MMM to the single element ∗*∗. We want to show that the definition of μ\muμ is also forced, by making using of the associativity and unit laws.

Let us start by considering the unit laws. The unit laws required are: λ=μ∘(η⊗1)\lambda = \mu \circ (\eta \otimes 1)λ=μ∘(η⊗1) and ρ=μ∘(1⊗η)\rho = \mu \circ (1 \otimes \eta)ρ=μ∘(1⊗η). Here λ\lambdaλ is the left identity morphism corresponding to a function λop:M→I⊗M\lambda^{op}:M \to I \otimes Mλop:M→I⊗M, acting by λop(m)=(∗,m)\lambda^{op}(m) = (*, m)λop(m)=(∗,m). Similarly, ρ\rhoρ is the right identity morphism corresponding to a function ρop:M→M⊗I\rho^{op}:M \to M \otimes Iρop:M→M⊗I, acting by ρop(m)=(m,∗)\rho^{op}(m) = (m,*)ρop(m)=(m,∗). (I am guessing as to the definitions of the identity morphisms. I haven't checked that these really are what required for Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop to be a monoidal category. I am also guessing that "1" here corresponds to the morphism that has corresponding function 1op1^{op}1op that is the identity function on MMM).

To expand these laws, we introduce the notation μop(m)=(μ1op(m),μ2op(m))\mu^{op}(m) = (\mu_1^{op}(m), \mu_2^{op}(m))μop(m)=(μ1op​(m),μ2op​(m)). Letting mmm be some element of MMM, the first unit law corresponds to: λop(m)=(ηop⊗1op)∘μop(m)\lambda^{op}(m) = (\eta^{op} \otimes 1^{op}) \circ \mu^{op}(m)λop(m)=(ηop⊗1op)∘μop(m), or equivalently (∗,m)=(ηop(μ1op(m)),μ2op(m))=(∗,μ2op(m))(*, m) = (\eta^{op}(\mu^{op}_1(m)), \mu^{op}_2(m)) = (*, \mu^{op}_2(m))(∗,m)=(ηop(μ1op​(m)),μ2op​(m))=(∗,μ2op​(m)). This implies that we must have μ2op(m)=m\mu^{op}_2(m) = mμ2op​(m)=m for any mmm in MMM.

The second unit law corresponds to ρop(m)=(1op⊗ηop)∘μop\rho^{op}(m) = (1^{op} \otimes \eta^{op}) \circ \mu^{op}ρop(m)=(1op⊗ηop)∘μop, or equivalently (m,∗)=(μ1op(m),ηop(μ2op(m))=(μ1op(m),∗)(m,*) = (\mu^{op}_1(m), \eta^{op}(\mu^{op}_2(m)) = (\mu^{op}_1(m), *)(m,∗)=(μ1op​(m),ηop(μ2op​(m))=(μ1op​(m),∗). This implies that we must have μ1op(m)=m\mu^{op}_1(m) = mμ1op​(m)=m for any mmm in MMM.

So, it seems like we only need the unit law to force the definition of μ\muμ. μ\muμ is the morphism corresponding to the function μop(m)=(m,m)\mu^{op}(m) = (m,m)μop(m)=(m,m).

However, I made some guesses as to the definition of Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop and the notation used in the unit laws. I am also a bit suspicious that I didn't have to use the associativity laws to force the definition of μ\muμ. Is there a error in the argument above?

(Another assumption I made was regarding the notational use of ⊗\otimes⊗: I assumed it corresponded to the corresponding functions "in parallel", so 1⊗η1 \otimes \eta1⊗η corresponds to the function (1op⊗ηop)(m)=(1op(m),ηop(m))(1^{op} \otimes \eta^{op})(m) = (1^{op}(m), \eta^{op}(m))(1op⊗ηop)(m)=(1op(m),ηop(m)).)
Nice! If you are like me, you must be feeling the neurons expanding :blush:
